page.title: Nominal Phrase - Articles & Demonstratives: Position and Agreement Features
page.introduction: Now we are ready to build the next part of the phrase structure tree. Look at the examples of noun phrases with articles and demonstratives that you keyed in (repeated below).

form.instruction: Since your language does not have articles or demonstratives expressed as separate words, we do not need to determine a syntactic position for them. You will be instructed to add the agreement features to nouns and their affixes when we deal with agreement again in the section on possessors.

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the article occur with respect to the noun?
radioGroup.radio: Before
After
Either side

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the articles appear on either side of the noun?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction
No, there are separate sets for each side

radioGroup.prompt: Is an article required to be present in every nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: No, an article is always optional
No, an article is optional with plural or mass nouns, but is required with singular nouns (disregard possessed nouns for now)
Yes, an article is always required

radioGroup.prompt: In which position(s) is the article required to be present for singular forms?
radioGroup.radio: Initial is required and final is optional
Final is required and initial is optional
Both positions are always required

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the demonstrative occur with respect to the noun?
radioGroup.radio: Before
After
Either side

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the demonstratives appear on either side of the noun?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction
No, there are separate sets for each side

radioGroup.prompt: Is a demonstrative required to be present in every nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: No, a demonstrative is always optional
No, a demonstrative is optional with plural or mass nouns, but is required with singular nouns (disregard possessed nouns for now)
Yes, a demonstrative is always required

radioGroup.prompt: In which position(s) is the demonstrative required to be present for singular forms?
radioGroup.radio: Initial is required and final is optional
Final is required and initial is optional
Both positions are always required

radioGroup.prompt: Do articles and demonstratives co-occur in the same nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: No, they occur in the same position, like in English

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the demonstrative or article occur with respect to the noun?
radioGroup.radio: Before
After
Either side

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the demonstratives and articles appear on either side of the noun?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction
No, there are separate sets for each side

radioGroup.prompt: Is a demonstrative or an article required to be present in every nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: No, the presence of a demonstrative or an article is always optional
No, a demonstrative or an article is optional with plural or mass nouns, but is required with singular nouns (disregard possessed nouns for now)
Yes, either a demonstrative or an article is always required

radioGroup.prompt: In which position(s) is the demonstrative or article required to be present for singular forms?
radioGroup.radio: Initial is required and final is optional
Final is required and initial is optional
Both positions are always required
Yes, both can be present in a single nominal phrase

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the demonstrative occur with respect to the noun?
radioGroup.radio: Before
After
Either side

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the demonstratives appear on either side of the noun?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction
No, there are separate sets for each side

radioGroup.prompt: Is a demonstrative required to be present in every nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: No, a demonstrative is always optional
No, a demonstrative is optional with plural or mass nouns, but is required with singular nouns (disregard possessed nouns for now)
Yes, a demonstrative is always required

radioGroup.prompt: In which position(s) is the demonstrative required to be present for singular forms?
radioGroup.radio: Initial is required and final is optional
Final is required and initial is optional
Both positions are always required

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the article occur with respect to the noun?
radioGroup.radio: Before
After
Either side

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the articles appear on either side of the noun?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction
No, there are separate sets for each side

radioGroup.prompt: Is an article required to be present in every nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: No, an article is always optional
No, an article is optional with plural or mass nouns, but is required with singular nouns (disregard possessed nouns for now)
Yes, an article is always required

radioGroup.prompt: In which position(s) is the article required to be present for singular forms?
radioGroup.radio: Initial is required and final is optional
Final is required and initial is optional
Both positions are always required

form.instruction: In the lexicon, mark those which can only occur before the noun with the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur after the noun with the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature on any articles or demonstratives which can occur on either side.

In the lexicon, mark those which can only occur before the noun with the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur after the noun with the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature on any articles which can occur on either side.

In the lexicon, mark those which can only occur before the noun with the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur after the noun with the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature on any demonstratives which can occur on either side.

To handle the number agreement, in the lexicon:
Mark the articlesdemonstrativesarticles and demonstratives that can only go with singular nouns with the feature singular.
Mark the articlesdemonstrativesarticles and demonstratives that can only go with plural nouns with the feature plural.
Do not add any feature for number agreement to ones like the in English which can go with either singular or plural nouns.
If your language makes a further distinction for dual marking, add the feature dual to the appropriate articles.demonstratives.articles and demonstratives.
We will assume that all nouns are singular by default. Therefore, only the plural nouns need to be marked. In the lexicon:
Add the feature plural to any affixes which can be added to a noun to make it plural.
Also, add the feature plural to any nouns which are inherently plural (such as scissors or pants in English), or exceptionally don't take an affix.
Any nouns which do not make a distinction between singular and plural forms, such as deer in English, need to have two entries in the lexicon, one marked with the feature plural and the other for singular (which can be explicitly marked or allowed to use the default). The parser will choose the correct form based on the context.
All mass nouns need to have the feature mass so that an articlea demonstrativean article or demonstrative will not be required.

To handle animacy agreement:
Mark the articlesdemonstrativesarticles and demonstratives that can only go with animate nouns with the feature animate.
Mark the articlesdemonstrativesarticles and demonstratives that can only go with inanimate nouns with the feature -animate.
Do not add any animacy agreement feature to those which can go with either animate or inanimate nouns.
We will assume that all (common) nouns are inanimate by default. Therefore, only the animate nouns need to be marked. In the lexicon, add the feature animate to any animate nouns, such as person, people, crowd, animal, and names of types of animals which are not proper names. (Proper names will be dealt with in
Proper Names and will be assumed to be animate by default.)

Add the gender features masculine, feminine, neuter to any articlesdemonstrativesarticles or demonstratives that can only go with that type of noun. Do not add any gender agreement feature to those which can go with either masculine or feminine nouns.
We will assume that all nouns are masculine by default. Therefore, only the feminine and neuter nouns need to be marked. In the lexicon:
Add the feature feminine to any affixes which can be added to a noun to make it feminine. Add the feature neuter to any affixes which can be added to a noun to make it neuter.
Also, add the feature feminine to any nouns which are inherently feminine, or exceptionally don't take an affix. Similarly, add the feature neuter to any nouns which are inherently neuter, or exceptionally don't take an affix.
Any nouns which do have the same form for both masculine and feminine, but which can take different forms of the articlesdemonstrativesarticles and demonstratives based on gender need to have two entries in the lexicon, one marked with the feature feminine and the other for masculine (which can be explicitly marked or allowed to use the default). The parser will choose the correct form based on the context.

To handle class marking and agreement:
Mark the articles demonstratives articles and demonstratives that can only go with a particular class with the feature class_##, where ## is replaced by a number between 1 and 99.
It may be the case that the same affixes that mark the class number on articles demonstratives articles and demonstratives (and possibly adjectives too) also mark the class number on nouns. If this is the case in your language, simply add the class feature to the affixes, and all the words will automatically come from the morphological parser with the class number marked.
Any cases where articles demonstratives articles, demonstratives or nouns do not have an affix which marks the class will require marking of the class feature on the particular lexical item in the lexicon.
